answers.q: 1 gram of aluminum will produce how many grams of potassium aluminum sulphate dodecahydrate
answers.a: About 17.6 g, assuming the aluminum is fully converted to potassium alum dodecahydrate (KAl(SO4)2·12H2O) using potassium sulphate (E515i) and sulfuric acid at 100% yield.

answers.q: 1..00 gram of aluminum will produce how many grams of potassium aluminum sulphate decahydrate
answers.a: About 16.3 g if the product is the decahydrate (KAl(SO4)2·10H2O) at 100% yield.

answers.q: assumming a 100 yeild 1 gram of aluminum will produce how many grams of potassium aluminum sulphate
answers.a: About 17.6 g as the common dodecahydrate; if you mean anhydrous KAl(SO4)2, it’s about 9.6 g per 1 g Al (both at 100% yield).

answers.q: how much "potassium sulphate" should i apply to raise *ppm
answers.a: K2SO4 is 44.9% potassium by weight, so grams needed ≈ 0.00223 × desired K ppm × volume in liters (e.g., raising K by 10 ppm in 100 L needs ~2.23 g K2SO4).

answers.q: how much potassium is in glucosamine sulphate
answers.a: In the common glucosamine sulfate 2KCl form, potassium is about 13% by weight (≈195 mg K per 1500 mg); sodium-chloride–stabilized forms contain no potassium.
